PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Wadena June 10, 1955

I have a great many memories of my childhood, but putting them on paper is another thing. We grew up at a wonderful time; we were always busy. I did not start school until I was 8. I helped mother as a housemaid & helped to mind cattle for father, so they were not enclosed in fences always, but although busy, had fun & peace. We lived near the school which served for church & Sunday school & young people gatherings for any reason. Here is a picture of the first school built in 1884 before I was born. The father came there in 1882. They had 6 children older than I was & 4 ready for school. Our first teacher I know nothing of, as he or she only taught 3 months. I call Mrs. Keith Webster our first teacher. She was Miss Moran & her home was there also. I remember her family. I met one of her grandsons here in Wadena in the bank. The pioneers of Morrison & Rocanville districts meet & knew each other by the name. We the girls are not easily tracked, but quite a number of us know where they are. One of the Rice's daughters was here too from Morrison. I had Mr. Rice in before he died. She is Mrs. Hal Johnson. We also had a daughter of Mr. Douglas, our pioneer minister. He said we were all christened, as we had students quite a while.

Our parents were particular, so to have us well cared for & had fun arranged for us too parties & picnics, as well as the Educational affairs. We later about 1894 had an additional factor, by the father of one family. He was a total teacher & taught a class, so we had a very good child. Our special picnic was the Rocanville picnic held three days yearly & by the banks of the Dr. Affell & there we had our quota of Indians as now, but we now minded their own affairs, unless molested, which some of our young half grown boys did. The Indians did get across & gone there, they dreaded scare, as they had horses, dogs, & plenty of good whips.

This picnic was annual about the 26th June & at
I have a great many memories of my childhood, but nothing there ever helped in another thing. We grew up in a wonderful time, we were always busy, I did not work hard until I was 16. I helped mother as a housemaid & helped to mind cattle for father. As they were still enclosed in fences, always, but although busy, had fun & games, we lived near the school which assured for advanced & Sunday school training.

In 1884 before I was from 6, father came back in 1882. They had 6 children then. I was 8 & ready for school. Our first teacher I knew nothing about her or she only taught 3 months. I call Mrs. Wilbur our first teacher.

Second teacher, she was Mrs. Supplee & how Rome wooed them. I remember his family. He kept one of his horses here in addition to the fourth. The horses of Mr. Johnson & Rosencrans died. I met & knew each other by the name, we the girls are still so easily traveled. But, built a number of houses there. Miss Mrs. Rice, our teacher, she was Mrs. Wilbur from Wisconsin. She also had a daughter of Mrs. Johnson, our friend, named Mrs. Johnson. We were all educated, as we had attended public schools arranged for us too. Part-time teachers, as well as the Educational Affairs. We left about 1894. Had an additional teacher, Mrs. Johnson.

Our family. He was a total teacher & taught a class, as we had a very good class. Our school house was the Rosencrans house. Built three days yearly, by the hands of the Rev. Ashby & Mrs. Ashby.

We had our Pueblo Indians over 1890, but as soon as needed, they moved. They Indians did get ours & gave them their deceased wives, as they had homes, dogs & plenty of good utensils.

Going back to the early pioneer days, one worry was fire. We generally, at seasons, went to bed seeing fires about four miles. Can remember some close ones. Another one was gophers. As the farms had small fields at first, & the gopher got more than the farmers, but they crushed their hindrances, & it was in a wonderful district—father built a new stone house (standing the Platte, a bit battered as its old) in 1895. A few yrs. later he sold out & retired to Mosomin. For a yr or so then went out to Vancouver. Father & mother both gone now. But mother lived to see 92 & some months. Another worry for we children, if we happened to be left alone was peddlers. More frightened of them than Indians. In winter we had bad blizzards, I remember them quite well. If our younger Bros. were out-in-one, they stayed together & have even travelled on hands & knees to right them selves.

Mother had to learn how to make bread from her Ontario friends but, they admitted she could make the best tea.

And our trading or buying was always done in the P.D. McNaughton store in Mosomin. I have a Bx. between always & Mr. Abery. On his home was, the sons work it was & he moved to Mr. Riley. Mr. Fisher has a cousin in Mosomin & son & Mrs Joseph Fisher our nearest neighbor & came in 1882 also.

Mrs Eliza (Stewart) Fisher.
Going back to the early pioneer days, we were very few in number, adventurous, willing to find away from the city for miles, can remember none other than Captain Ben was captain of the farm. Land owned by Mr. and Mrs. John Johnson. They purchased their land in 1898. A new house was built in a wonderful district. Father built a new house.

Leaving the Platte, we returned to Nebraska. We lived there until 1920 when we moved to South Dakota. We had a hard time adjusting to the new climate. Our young boys were out in the world. If our children were able to adjust, they would have been successful, but, they admitted she could make the best tea.

P.D. We thought about buying an old house in the city, but, we always came home. We moved to South Dakota in 1970. I believe there was a reason in moving there. A son of Mr. Joseph Fisher also moved there in 1882.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

My husband gave children names & where they and their children live. Let me add, our oldest daughter was a teacher & is still active in the affairs of the district. The two younger ones married. The youngest one being only an adult & worked in the same district & depression spoiled some of our plans.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

We had a wonderful community, it was far superior to the attitudes & today in some ways. Had good supervision of children & schools etc. & the schools, but roads, cars & tractors, all added to the progress of the west. Land kept strictly to 6 days short, those work in summer days.
